body.head.byline: By VIVIAN S. TOY; With Valerie Cotsalas, Suzanne Hamlin and Lisa Prevost

abstract.p: Sampling of housing on market in New York City metropolitan area; photos (M)

block.p: Upper West Side Co-op $1,595,000
MANHATTAN: 24A West 90th Street (between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue)
A two-bedroom, two-bath duplex apartment with a working fireplace and a lovely private garden. Edward Herson, Halstead Property (212) 381-2293; www.halstead.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,084 a month

PROS: This unusual co-op makes great use of the basement by opening up part of it to the ground floor and giving the basement den 18-foot ceilings. There are plenty of closets and additional storage space, plus a narrow room off the den that could be used as an office.
CONS: The kitchen and bathrooms, though in good condition, are dated. The railings and catwalk above the basement opening are not very child-friendly.
Port Jefferson Colonial $795,000
SUFFOLK: 108 High Street
A charming three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath colonial built in 1855, with harbor views. Details include five fireplaces (two working) with built-in kindling closets. Open house Sunday, 2 to 4 p.m.
Lorin Alvarez (631) 338-2394, and Pat Johnson (631) 384-1133, Jolie Powell Realty; www.jprealtor.com
TAXES: $5,587 a year
PROS: The owners have added central air, three heat zones, new wiring, plumbing and roof.
CONS: The second-floor full bath needs updating.
Financial District Co-op $769,000
MANHATTAN: 65 Nassau Street (at John Street), #10C
A one-bedroom, one-bath with a large dining area that could easily be converted to a second bedroom. Richard Rothbloom, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 452-4485; www.brownharrisstevens.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,442 a month
PROS: Nine tall windows in this loftlike corner apartment let in lots of light. The building is just steps from the nine subway lines at the Fulton Street transit hub.
CONS: The bedroom is open to the living room, affording very little privacy. There is no bathtub.
Park Slope Co-op $420,000
BROOKLYN: 27 Prospect Park West (at Montgomery Place)

An 825-square-foot ground-floor apartment in a prewar building, with one bedroom and one and a half baths. Eric Heras (718) 923-8044, James Mathieu (718) 923-8010, the Corcoran Group; www.corcoran.com. Open house Sunday, 2:30 to 4 p.m.
MAINTENANCE: $1,263 a month
PROS: Fronting on Prospect Park, the apartment has its own set-back entrance. It could legally be reconverted into a doctor's office.
CONS: No dogs are allowed, and updating is needed.
Rowayton Mediterranean $1,749,000
CONNECTICUT: 4 Covewood Drive
A stucco home with four bedrooms, two and a half baths, a new kitchen and a patio, on a dead-end street. Pam Elliott, Wheeler Real Estate (203) 656-6538, www.wheelerrealestatect.com
TAXES: $9,450

PROS: Built in 1940, this renovated home offers a charming alternative to the usual colonial design, with gothic-inspired features like rooftop crenelation and arched windows and doorways. The sunken family room has a radiant-heat floor and a wet bar.
CONS: There is no garage.
